<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 514, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the stretching of a spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 332, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the set up.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 128, 814, 504]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 502, 532, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[label]Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 146, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 533, 616, 551]]<|/det|>
The metre rule is clamped in position near to the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, show clearly how you would use a set square to obtain an accurate reading of the position of the bottom of the coiled part of the spring from the metre rule. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 146, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 610, 920, 643]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 shows the spring drawn to actual size. On Fig. 1.2, measure the length \(L\) of the coiled part of the spring.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 650, 250, 752]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 766, 262, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 796, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 828, 144, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 828, 920, 861]]<|/det|>
The student adds a load \(P = 0.20 \text{N}\) to the spring. He records the new length \(l\) of the coiled part of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 873, 920, 906]]<|/det|>
He repeats the procedure using loads \(P = 0.40 \text{N}, 0.60 \text{N}, 0.80 \text{N}\) and \(1.00 \text{N}\). All the readings are recorded in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 42, 512, 58]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 101, 603, 246]]<|/det|>
\(P/\mathrm {N}\)\(l/\mathrm {mm}\)

0.4026

0.8035
1.0041

Start both axes at the origin (0,0). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[205, 282, 791, 695]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 747, 918, 765]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 777, 148, 794]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 777, 918, 826]]<|/det|> The intercept on the \(y\)-axis of the graph is numerically equal to the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring when \(P = 0\). Determine the value of \(l_{0}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 833, 918, 853]]<|/det|>
l_{0} = ............................................................ [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 924, 920, 942]]<|/det|> [Total: 11]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 662, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the refraction of light in a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1 shows her ray-trace sheet. She places a transparent block on the ray-trace sheet and draws the outline ABCD of the block. The student uses pins to mark the positions of objects and images.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 751, 765]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[725, 797, 845, 845]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Continue the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) so that it passes through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 190, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 658, 136]]<|/det|>

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 662, 167]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw a line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at least \(7 \text{cm}\) long above side \(\mathbf{AB}\) and at an angle \(i = 30^\circ\) to the left of the normal. Label the end of the line \(\mathbf{E}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 242, 175, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), to act as objects, on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 273, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 144, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
The student looks from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 2.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block. She adjusts her line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 365, 170, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 365, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between her eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 411, 173, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 411, 702, 429]]<|/det|>
The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked on the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 180, 462]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 444, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line through the block until it extends to just outside the outline of the block. Label this end of the line \(\mathbf{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 742, 922, 760]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the length of time taken for ice cubes to melt when they are placed in water. She uses beakers of water at different temperatures to investigate how the initial temperature of the water affects the time taken for the ice cubes to melt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the initial temperature of the water affects the time taken for the ice cubes to melt.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 420, 198]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 228, 227]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 280, 243]]<|/det|>
supply of ice cubes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 260, 258]]<|/det|>
250 cm³ beakers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 285, 273]]<|/det|>
supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 324, 305]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 492, 336]]<|/det|>
• write a list of additional apparatus to use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 494, 368]]<|/det|>
• explain how to carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 487, 399]]<|/det|>
